content.text: *Japan's incoming PM Takaichi names Aso party vice president*

Sanae Takaichi, newly elected leader of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party and expected to become the country's first female prime minister, named former premier Taro Aso LDP vice president and ex-finance minister Shunichi Suzuki secretary-general. Analysts say Aso and Suzuki could temper large fiscal spending plans, even as stocks rose and the yen fell on expectations of stimulus and a slower pace of rate hikes. Her path remains politically tricky: the LDP needs coalition support to command a majority in parliament, and she still must secure enough votes in the Diet to take office.
*Illinois, Chicago sue to block Trump National Guard deployment*

Illinois and the city of Chicago filed a lawsuit on Monday to stop a federalized deployment of National Guard troops to the city, arguing the move is unconstitutional. President Trump has threatened to invoke the Insurrection Act to bypass court restrictions on such deployments, intensifying a clash with Democratic-led states.
*Israel deports 171 Gaza aid flotilla activists, including Thunberg*

Israel intercepted a Gaza-bound aid flotilla at sea and, after several days in detention, deported 171 participants on Monday to Greece and Slovakia, including Swedish activist Greta Thunberg. Some activists allege mistreatment in custody, which Israel denies, and several participants remain in prison pending further proceedings. President Trump criticized Thunberg following her arrival in Athens.
*Madagascar president appoints army general Zafisambo as prime minister*

Madagascar’s President Andry Rajoelina on Monday appointed army general Ruphin Fortunat Zafisambo as prime minister, a week after dissolving the government amid youth-led protests over power and water shortages. Demonstrations continued in Antananarivo as security forces used tear gas to disperse crowds, injuring at least one person, while some protesters demanded Rajoelina resign within 48 hours. The appointment was presented as a bid to defuse unrest over his rule.
*UNESCO board backs Egypt's el-Enany with 55 votes*

UNESCO's executive board voted Monday to back Egyptian Egyptologist and former antiquities and tourism minister Khaled el-Enany as the organization’s next director-general, giving him 55 of 57 votes over Congo’s Firmin Edouard Matoko. His nomination now goes to the General Conference for ratification on November 6 in Uzbekistan; if confirmed, he would become UNESCO’s first director-general from an Arab country and the second from Africa, taking office November 14. The United States, which has announced its withdrawal from the agency, did not take part in the vote.
*Blizzard in Tibet's Everest area traps hikers; 350 evacuated*

Hundreds of hikers were caught by an unseasonal blizzard on the Tibetan side of Mount Everest over the weekend, with rescue teams guiding many to safety and continuing efforts for others. About 350 people reached the town of Qudang by Sunday and were safe by noon Monday, while roughly 200 others were still being assisted; at least one trekker died, according to local reports. Nepalese authorities said all tourists on their side were safe and that trekking to Everest Base Camp had restarted.
*Venezuela says 'false flag' plot targeting US embassy foiled*

Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro said on Monday that authorities foiled a "false flag" plan by local extremists to plant explosives at the US embassy in Caracas. He said his government warned Washington about the alleged plot, which he claimed aimed to aggravate tensions with the United States, including a dispute over drug trafficking. The US embassy in Caracas has operated with only a small number of local staff since diplomatic ties were severed in 2019.
*Gaza war at two years as U.S.-backed talks proceed*

Two years after the October 7, 2023 Hamas-led attacks that killed around 1,200 people in Israel and saw 251 hostages taken, fighting in Gaza continues. Reported Palestinian deaths range from around 66,000 to over 67,000, amid a UN-declared famine and widespread destruction, while Israel's goals of freeing all hostages and eliminating Hamas have not been achieved. Recent negotiations under a U.S.-backed plan put forward by President Trump in Cairo aim to exchange prisoners, enable a phased Israeli withdrawal and end the war—raising hopes of returning hostages and halting the fighting.
*Update: US shutdown reaches seventh day after Senate votes*

In the latest development, the US government shutdown reached its seventh day as the Senate again rejected competing funding measures. President Trump briefly signaled openness to discussing health care subsidies central to Democrats’ demands, then said talks would begin only after the government reopens. Senate GOP leaders considered canceling next week’s recess as the House planned to remain out this week, underscoring the lack of movement.
*France's Macron gives Lecornu 48 hours to salvage government*

In Paris on Tuesday, outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu began two days of cross-party talks under a 48-hour deadline set by President Emmanuel Macron to try to assemble a workable cabinet and agenda. His cabinet, unveiled Sunday evening, collapsed in about 14 hours on Monday, making it the shortest-lived administration in modern French history. Macron signaled he could call snap legislative elections if negotiations fail, against the backdrop of a hung parliament since mid-2024 snap polls.
*Israel marks Oct. 7 anniversary amid Egypt ceasefire talks*

Israelis held memorials on Tuesday to mark two years since the Hamas-led Oct. 7, 2023 attacks, which killed about 1,200 people and saw 251 hostages taken. Commemorations in Tel Aviv and southern communities came as indirect ceasefire negotiations between Israel and Hamas continued in Egypt under a US-backed framework, raising hopes for a hostage deal.
*Israel, Hamas in Egypt talks on US Gaza plan*

Israel and Hamas held the first day of indirect negotiations in Egypt on Monday, with mediators describing a “positive atmosphere” and talks set to resume Tuesday. The US-brokered plan’s initial phase centers on releasing Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners and a partial Israeli withdrawal, while longer-term issues such as disarmament and Gaza’s governance remain unresolved. President Trump said he was “pretty sure” a deal is possible and urged negotiators to “MOVE FAST,” though the White House has avoided setting a firm deadline.
